title: Who pays to fortress Australian banks?
text:
Increasing the amount of capital that needs to be held is an expensive exercise for banks. Photo: James Davies
It is a near certainty that banks will pass on some of their newly imposed capital safety cost to their customers by way of charging higher interest on loans or paying lower interest on deposits.
The finance regulator APRA has placed higher capital requirements on the four large banks plus Macquarie - which means they will need to raise a combined $12 billion.
Some higher risk loans that have been approved in the past may no longer make the cut.
In large part the booming residential property market is behind the regulator move to ensure that the banks have more capital in reserve against the mortgages they write.
The heated property market which many experts say is displaying all the hallmarks of a bubble has worried regulators.
Six months ago the regulator took some more gentle steps to flex its muscle to hose down lending to landlords but the the mortgage lending figures suggest there has been plenty of growth and property prices in Sydney and Melbourne are still rising on the back of strong demand.
The recent Financial Services Inquiry urged APRA and the government to fortify the financial system by mandating the banks to bolster capital reserves.
More stringent capital needs will also prompt banks to take a more hardline assessment of their lending risk.
Some higher risk loans that have been approved in the past may no longer make the cut - this includes the booming sector of investment loans to buy real estate.
Increasing the amount of capital that needs to be held is an expensive exercise for banks and it increase their costs.
The banks will have two choices when faced with higher costs. One is to content themselves with producing a lower return on capital. This outcome is possible but not likely.
The other option is to pass on the cost increase to customers. Like most businesses that face higher costs the pass through is most common - unless competition doesn't allow it.
It's a fair bet that customers will see some subtle repricing. Bank might just trim those discounts to the list price interest rates or adjust fees.
But there are only five banks faced with the new capital requirements. And while it can't be said that they will act in concert, history suggests their response will be similar.
Having said that some banks are more exposed than others to the new rules imposed by ARPA that will come into effect in a year.
Those with larger mortgage books will be hit disproportionately harder.
Westpac has already said it will be up for about $3 billion to get its capital levels into appropriate territory and the Commonwealth Bank says it needs to bolster by 97 basis points (almost 1 per cent). It is estimated this could cost CBA up to $4 billion.
The National Australia Bank, which is in the process of raising billions via an equity placement and asset sales, and has a much smaller mortgage book, will still need to add 70 basis point in capital .
ANZ which also a smaller mortgage loan books that the two market leaders said it will need $2.3 billion in additional capital - or 55 basis points.
The banks already knew the increase in credit risk weighting on mortgages was coming and have instituted pre-emptive moves to raise additional funds. Some like Westpac have used dividend reinvestment schemes and sold down its stake in BT Investment Management to bolster capital.
NAB is in the process of selling its UK and US assets and has undertaken a $5.5 billion equity issue.
The bad news for the banks - and potentially for bank customers - is that the regulator is not yet done.
Last week it said the big five Australian banks would need to add 200 basis points of capital to be comfortably among the top quartile in the world. The moves announced on Monday will get them less than half of the way.
While it is clearly a headwind for the major banks, and one that will place them on a more equal risk footing with their smaller regional bank rivals, the market did not react in a particularly negative fashion. By the end of the day all the share prices of all held their ground other than Westpac whose price slipped marginally.
It is because the need for additional capital has been so well flagged by the regulator and the banks - rather than the fact that it isn't a genuine pressure point on their balance sheets.
It represents another headwind at a time when there are not enough offsetting tailwinds.
A share price response is more likely in the event that any of the majors decide they need to undertake a rights issue or curtail increases in dividend
